Topic.Title: Why so little spam here & FB and ZNGA have lots?

Message.Msg: There is a lot of spam and bad behavior. You can bet if this type of behavior occurred at a Marissa Mayer meeting the instigators would be at the curb in a heart beat. There is only one way for this environment to change: Monitors. In just a few days it would be cleaned up. Or, Yahoo could seek volunteer monitors and let the users police themselves. But some type of action needs doing. And oddly, at the bottom of a board Yahoo asks for ideas. I read through many. More than half express the problems you face. Many make very good suggestions. Yet no action from Yahoo. Perhaps it's true the financial boards will be closed with the rest at the end of March. Keep trying, tru. You're not alone.

Message.Title: Alibaba follows the money for IPO destination
Message.Msg: The destination of Alibaba Group's much-anticipated initial public offering will likely be determined by this catchphrase: "Show me the money". Market analysts yesterday said the IPO for the mainland's largest e-commerce company would be conducted where it could get the highest value for its shares in what could be the biggest technology-related offering this year. Hangzhou-based Alibaba is apparently keen to explore its best options as its senior finance executives held closed-door discussions in Hong Kong on Wednesday with a representative of Nasdaq OMX, the operator of the Nasdaq Stock Market in New York. "It would be a matter of pride for a Chinese company like Alibaba to have its public offering on Chinese soil, but it must consider where it can get the highest price-earnings ratio," VC Brokerage director Louis Tse Ming-kwong said: In a research note published last month, Morgan Stanley analyst Jordan Monahan calculated that Alibaba was worth between US$66 billion and US$128 billion, based on its forecast net income of US$2.28 billion this year and US$3.55 billion next year. He suggested a share offer this year would value the company at US$80 billion.

Message.Title: FNHC - Article out yesterday indicating co. selling at 50% of its investment portfolio value w/zero debt.
Message.Msg: Insiders are buying as well as one big mutual fund co. which just took a 8% stake. Earnings were up 180% and to be released again in 5 days. Dividend policy just reinstated and they normally pay around an 8% return. Also trading at 50% of price target, which makes sense I guess. In the last CC they indicated that book value is growing again. The article is right there on yahoo under FNHC.

Topic.Title: Alibaba follows the money for IPO destination

Message.Msg: Tse said: "Alibaba must ask itself: which market can afford such a big IPO that could be many times oversubscribed?" He pointed out that Nasdaq's attraction for Alibaba was that it was the preferred market for many information-technology, media and telecommunications companies. Li Zhongzhi, an analyst at Ping An Securities in Shenzhen, said Alibaba's shareholders - including Japan's Softbank, internet pioneer Yahoo and private-equity investors such as China Investment Corporation - "will prefer the flexibility of the Nasdaq or Hong Kong, where they can cash out their shares easily".

Message.Title: Alibaba IPO to Bypass Hong Kong and Head to NASDAQ!
Message.Msg: According to sources close to Hong Kong’s South China Morning Post, e-commerce giant Alibaba might bypass the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and instead take its huge IPO to NASDAQ. The paper claims that Alibaba executives met with NASDAQ representatives for a secret meeting in the Chinese principality yesterday afternoon.

Topic.Title: Alibaba may choose New York over Hong Kong for its hotly anticipated IPO

Message.Msg: Full article.... The destination of Alibaba Group's much-anticipated initial public offering will likely be determined by this catchphrase: "Show me the money". Market analysts yesterday said the IPO for the mainland's largest e-commerce company would be conducted where it could get the highest value for its shares in what could be the biggest technology-related offering this year. Hangzhou-based Alibaba is apparently keen to explore its best options as its senior finance executives held closed-door discussions in Hong Kong on Wednesday with a representative of Nasdaq OMX, the operator of the Nasdaq Stock Market in New York. "It would be a matter of pride for a Chinese company like Alibaba to have its public offering on Chinese soil, but it must consider where it can get the highest price-earnings ratio," VC Brokerage director Louis Tse Ming-kwong said: In a research note published last month, Morgan Stanley analyst Jordan Monahan calculated that Alibaba was worth between US$66 billion and US$128 billion, based on its forecast net income of US$2.28 billion this year and US$3.55 billion next year. He suggested a share offer this year would value the company at US$80 billion. Tse said: "Alibaba must ask itself: which market can afford such a big IPO that could be many times oversubscribed?" He pointed out that Nasdaq's attraction for Alibaba was that it was the preferred market for many information-technology, media and telecommunications companies. Li Zhongzhi, an analyst at Ping An Securities in Shenzhen, said Alibaba's shareholders - including Japan's Softbank, internet pioneer Yahoo and private-equity investors such as China Investment Corporation - "will prefer the flexibility of the Nasdaq or Hong Kong, where they can cash out their shares easily". "But it will be difficult to make US investors recognise the full value of Alibaba," Li said. Alibaba is currently being restructured into 25 business units. Alibaba, which entrepreneur Jack Ma Yun started ou

Topic.Title: yahoo forums were down for over 2 hours

Message.Msg: It wasn't just the forums; news, finance, and even the dedicated AD servers were unreachable during this event. Whether deliberate attack, or just a massive tech fail, their response and their slow recovery is not impressive. Yahoo has been in this business a long time and surely their security and continuity/contigency managers would have recognized the risk, planned accordingly and briefed the top decision makers. It will be interesting to see what the story is.

Topic.Title: Notifications.

Message.Msg: Don't hold your breath. First it was teh widespread email hacking; today it was TWO HOURS of total outage (http://www.cnbc.com/id/100538723). Yahoo doesn't seem to be able maintain a secure, stable environment that keeps their GIG from being reamed from one end to the other. It would be interesting to see their investment (capital and per capita workers) in transport layer (and below) support compared to best in class...or not.

Topic.Title: Short this baby!!!!

Message.Msg: I short every spike up and cover $1 cheaper and go long. Like taking candy from a baby. Instead of just making money trading one way I go both. I make so much more that way. I added more to short position today at the open. This will correct to $21.75 before moving higher. Count on it.

Topic.Title: New income.

Message.Msg: This is one thing YHOO Longs should keep an eye and do a follow up. Common sense, Alibaba Etao should use YHOO search engine to be different from Baidu and goog their competitors in China.

Topic.Title: New income.

Message.Msg: And as part of the 2012 deal Alibaba paid a one time $550 million fee for a perpetual license for existing Technology and Intellectual Property. No future royalty payments coming. -#..upon the consummation of the Initial Repurchase, Alibaba will pay to the Company (Yahoo) $550 million in satisfaction of certain future royalty payments under the existing Technology and Intellectual Property License Agreement by and between the Company and Alibaba ..#-

Topic.Title: Short this baby!!!!

Message.Msg: Buy, sell, short and cover, rinse and repeat. Make money on every movement and don´t bother trying to guess where Yahoo will be next week or month or year. Make more in a week than those holding make in a year.
